Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Investigations of Nanolaser Physics: Statistical Properties, Thermal Stability, and Temporal Dynamics of Light Emission

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fundamental Investigations of Nanolaser Physics: Statistical Properties, Thermal Stability, and Temporal Dynamics of Light Emission

Nanoscale lasers, with dimensions smaller than their operating wavelength, have the potential to offer unprecedented communication, sensing, and illumination functionalities, due to their incredibly small footprint and energy budget. However, the fundamental properties of nanolaser light emission are poorly understood, in particular their statistical properties. The objectives of this research are to develop a theoretical model describing the dynamics of nanolasers based on a rigorous set of measurements and to demonstrate electronically controlled nanolasers operating at room temperature. These nanoscale lasers would find applications in quantum communications and computation networks for secure communications and for modeling of complex systems like the Earth's climate. In addition, nanolasers have the potential for sensing bio-chemical agents in extremely small volumes for healthcare applications.


The overall significance of the proposed effort is to further advance the fundamental knowledge of nanoscale lasers. Nanolasers, which are formed from metallic, insulating, and semi-conducting materials, have temperature-dependent properties. The thermal stability of these lasers is intricately coupled to their emission properties. Additionally, the light emission and thermal properties generally evolve in time. Therefore, a theoretical model describing the dynamics of nanolasers, coupled with their statistical and thermal characteristics will be developed. The Purcell effect in quantum dissipative systems will be investigated to describe the sub-threshold behavior in nanolasers. Experimental objectives of this project include the design and analysis of second and/or higher order coherence measurements tailored for semiconductor telecom wavelength nanolasers at various temperatures. Electrically pumped coaxial nanolasers for continuous wave operation at room temperature will be fabricated and characterized. Results of these experiments will lead to construct more accurate models of nanolaser dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscale light emitters have recently become excellent candidates for advancing the science of light sources on the nanoscale, and form the building-blocks of chip-scale photonic circuits for various applications including optical interconnections, switching, sensing and efficient lighting. Reducing the size of light sources that are immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI) can improve packing density, reduce power consumption, and increase the strength of cavity-emitter interactions, which may lead to higher laser efficiency, faster switching time, and thresholdless behavior. Because of their size, nanolasers may be packed at enormous densities, compared to their macroscopic counterparts. With the electrically-pumped metallo-dielectric laser of a diameter of 1.5μm that we demonstrated in the past, if we assume a pitch of twice this length, then over 30,000 electronically controlled, metal-clad nanolasers could be placed in the same footprint as 4 commercial VCSELs. Using an electrically pumped coaxial structure, it is conceivable that this number could be even greater. Such a densely packed array would be ideal for high-resolution imaging/sensing. Depending on their Purcell factors, metal-clad nanolasers may exhibit relaxation bandwidths that make them suitable for receiving, transmitting, and processing information at the chip-scale. The combined density, low power consumption, and potentially fast operation, make metal-clad nanolaser arrays strong candidates for light sources of future integrated photonic circuits. This research project not only advanced the basic science and technology of nanolasers, but also paved the way for development of ubiquitous sensor arrays that may enable unprecedented levels of biomedical, environmental, and structural health monitoring, with energy efficient and extremely small form factors. In addition to enabling nanolaser applications, these nanoscale resonators should provide a powerful platform for the development of other QED devices and metamaterials in which strong atom–field interactions generate new functionalities. 

During the course of the project we have identified and investigated several fundamental nanolaser properties and technical challenges.  Specifically, we developed electrically pumped nanolasers technology and carried out theoretical/numerical studies to improved fundamental understanding of nanolasers. We also developed a novel method of measuring the time-dependent second order correlation properties of nanolasers with unity spontaneous emission factor, which enabled dynamic characterization of statistical properties of nanoscale light emitters with demonstration of dynamic hysteresis of light emission.  This method introduces a novel technique to clearly determine transition from spontaneous to stimulated emission, revealing unambiguously the behavious of nanolasers with unity spontaneous emission factor. We also formulated Purcell effect in quantum dissipative systems to advance the fundamental understanding of Purcell factor and using the time-dependent second order correlation method demonstrated experimentally the sub-threshold behavior of nanolasers. Finally, we started an investigation of coupled nanolaser oscillators which will enable us to establish fundamental understanding of coupled nanolaser oscillators in large array configurations to enable novel applications in computing and optical information processing systems.  The project provided scientific training for students at graduate and undergraduate levels. Their training included developing rigorous electromagnetic, electronic and thermal modeling tools to design and analyze nanoscale resonators, light emitters and nanolasers.  They also are trained in establishing the advanced tools and techniques required to fabricate these nanoscale devices, and use advanced characterization techniques such as micro photoluminescence, spectroscopy and measurements of statistical properties of light emitters using intensity correlation methods. We continued our outreach, education and collaborative efforts with San Diego middle and high schools. Through our relationships with the Sweetwater, Preuss, and High Tech High Schools, we successfully engaged students of diverse ethnicity, gender and economic backgrounds in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM). We continued the ongoing RET, REU, and COSMOS programs.  For this project we used traditional means and develop new mechanisms for data dissemination.
